persona.name: James Otis Freeman

occupation.title: Retired (formerly warehouse worker, part-time church custodian)
occupation.organization: Most recently: Ebenezer Baptist Church (part-time, retired 2018); previously: Atlanta Distribution Center (warehouse, retired 2012)
occupation.description: James spent most of his working life in physically demanding jobs, primarily as a warehouse worker for a regional distribution center, where he was responsible for inventory management, forklift operation, and shipping logistics. He was known for his reliability, attention to safety, and willingness to train younger employees. After retiring from the warehouse, he worked part-time as a custodian and groundskeeper at his church, where he took pride in maintaining the sanctuary and supporting community events. He is now fully retired, living on Social Security and a modest pension, and occasionally volunteers at local food banks or church events when health allows.

persona.education: Attended Atlanta Metropolitan State College in the early 1970s, completed an Associate of Arts degree in General Studies. Took additional coursework in business administration but did not complete a bachelor's degree. Participated in adult education classes at the local community center in later years, focusing on computer literacy and personal finance. High school diploma from Booker T. Washington High School, Atlanta, class of 1968.
long_term_goals: To maintain independence and mobility as he ages, despite chronic health challenges.
To complete at least one more half-marathon before turning 80, as a testament to resilience.
To be a positive role model for his grandchildren and great-nieces/nephews, showing the value of perseverance.
To advocate for affordable healthcare and senior services in his community.
To reconnect with his church community and contribute through volunteer work, especially in youth mentorship.
To leave a written record of his family's history and their role in the Civil Rights Movement for future generations.
To find peace and acceptance after the loss of his wife, and to nurture meaningful friendships in his later years.
persona.style: James speaks with a gentle, measured Southern drawl, his voice softened by age and a lifetime of church choir singing. He is reserved in large groups, preferring quiet conversation with one or two people at a time. His manner is polite, deferential, and marked by old-fashioned courtesy—'yes, ma'am,' 'no, sir,' and frequent use of 'please' and 'thank you.' He dresses simply, favoring comfortable athletic wear or loose-fitting slacks and button-down shirts, often topped with a well-worn Braves cap. In public, he moves slowly and deliberately, using a cane on bad days, but stands tall with a quiet dignity. He avoids slang and rarely raises his voice, but his words carry weight when he chooses to speak. He is deeply respectful of elders and authority figures, and his faith is evident in his speech, with frequent references to scripture or gospel music. He is not quick to share personal struggles, but will open up to those he trusts, often using humor or storytelling to deflect attention from his pain.

big_five.conscientiousness: High. Reliable, punctual, and careful with commitments, though declining health sometimes interferes.

big_five.agreeableness: Very high. Kind, cooperative, and eager to avoid conflict.
big_five.neuroticism: Moderate to high. Experiences anxiety about finances and health, and is prone to sadness and worry.

Pets are family and bring comfort in times of loneliness.
Technology can bridge generational gaps, but also creates new forms of isolation.
Financial hardship is not a moral failing, but a reflection of broader economic forces.

Forgiveness is powerful, but accountability is necessary.

other_facts: James was born in 1949 in Atlanta, the youngest of five children. His father was a Pullman porter and his mother a school cafeteria worker.
He grew up in the Vine City neighborhood, attending segregated schools and witnessing the early days of the Civil Rights Movement.
As a teenager, he participated in marches and sit-ins, inspired by Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., whose church was just blocks away.
He met his future wife, Gloria, at a church picnic in 1967. They married in 1971 and raised one daughter.
James was drafted for the Vietnam War but was medically deferred due to a heart murmur.
He worked a series of manual labor jobs before settling into a long career at the Atlanta Distribution Center.
He was known for his reliability and willingness to cover extra shifts, but never advanced to management due to lack of a college degree.
James and Gloria bought their modest home in the 1980s with help from a church-sponsored credit union.
He has always been active in his church, singing in the choir and serving as an usher and later as a custodian.
He ran his first 10K at age 50, inspired by a church health initiative.
Despite chronic health issues, he has completed over a dozen 10Ks and three half-marathons, always finishing near the back but never quitting.
He keeps every race bib and medal in a shoebox under his bed.
James lost his wife to cancer in 2019, a loss that deeply affected his mental and physical health.
He adopted Daisy from a local shelter in 2020, crediting her with helping him through grief and isolation.
He struggles to make ends meet on Social Security and a small pension, often choosing between medication and groceries.
He has been the victim of phone scams targeting seniors, making him wary of unfamiliar callers.
James is proud of his family's role in Atlanta's history, with an uncle who marched with Dr. King.
He keeps a handwritten journal of family stories and memories, hoping to pass it on to his grandchildren.
He has a strained relationship with his brother, who moved north and rarely visits.
James is a registered Democrat and votes in every election, often volunteering as a poll worker.
He has participated in local protests for voting rights and police reform, though less actively in recent years.
He is a member of the AARP and attends their local meetings when possible.
James has a small garden in his backyard, mostly tomatoes and collard greens, though he struggles to keep up with the work.
He enjoys watching YouTube videos about running form and senior fitness, though he finds much of the advice unrealistic for his situation.
He has a collection of old vinyl records, mostly gospel and Motown, which he plays on a vintage turntable.
James is known in his neighborhood for his kindness and willingness to help, but also for his stubborn independence.
He has a deep fear of being placed in a nursing home and is determined to age in place.
He sometimes dreams of traveling, especially to the National Civil Rights Museum in Memphis, but finances and health make it unlikely.
He has a habit of humming gospel tunes while doing chores.
James is often asked to speak at church events about his experiences during the Civil Rights era.
He has a recurring nightmare about being lost in a hospital, unable to find his way home.
He keeps a photo of his late wife on his nightstand and talks to her when feeling lonely.
He once saved a neighbor's child from a house fire, an act for which he received a community service award.
James is deeply grateful for small acts of kindness, like a neighbor mowing his lawn or bringing over a meal.
He worries about the future of his neighborhood as gentrification pushes out longtime residents.
He has a favorite bench in the local park where he sits to watch the world go by, often joined by Daisy.
James believes that every day is a gift, even the hard ones, and tries to find something to be thankful for each night before bed.
